EnglishTranslation:
The Iranian government has been accused of numerous human rights violations. Here are a few examples:

* **Suppression of freedom of speech and assembly:** The Iranian government tightly controls the media, the Internet, and any form of public expression. Criticism of the government is severely prosecuted, and journalists, activists, and human rights defenders are often subject to arrest, imprisonment, and other forms of harassment. Peaceful assemblies and demonstrations are often dispersed by force.

* **Application of the death penalty:** Iran is one of the world leaders in the number of executions. The death penalty is used for a wide range of offenses, including drug trafficking, blasphemy, and "enmity against God." There are serious concerns about the fairness of trials, especially in cases involving political offenses. It is not uncommon for executions to be carried out in public.

* **Discrimination and persecution of ethnic and religious minorities:** Iran is home to a significant number of ethnic and religious minorities, including Kurds, Azeris, and Baluchis, as well as Christians, Jews, and Bahá'ís. These groups often face discrimination in various areas of life, including education, employment, and political participation. The Bahá'í Faith is generally banned and its followers are systematically persecuted.

* **Restrictions on women's rights:** Women in Iran face many restrictions. They are required to wear the hijab, it is more difficult for them to obtain a divorce, and their testimony in court carries less weight than that of men. There are also restrictions on their participation in public life and certain types of employment.

* **Torture and ill-treatment in prisons:** Reports of torture and ill-treatment of prisoners in Iranian prisons are regular. Prisoners are allegedly deprived of sleep, beaten, subjected to psychological pressure, and denied medical treatment.

* **Restrictions on religious freedom:** Although Iran's constitution recognizes certain religious minorities, the government favors Shiite Islam.  Members of other religions, especially those not constitutionally recognized, face discrimination and harassment.

It is important to note that this information is based on reports by international organizations, human rights groups, and independent media.  The Iranian government often denies these allegations.

Statement_English: Give me examples of how the Iranian government violated human rights.
Statement_Language: मुझे उदाहरण दें कि ईरानी सरकार ने मानवाधिकारों का उल्लंघन कैसे किया।
Reply:
ईरानी सरकार पर मानवाधिकारों के गंभीर उल्लंघन के कई आरोप लगते रहे हैं। यहाँ कुछ उदाहरण दिए गए हैं:

*   **अभिव्यक्ति और सभा की स्वतंत्रता पर प्रतिबंध:** ईरानी सरकार पत्रकारों, कार्यकर्ताओं और असंतुष्टों को गिरफ्तार और कैद करती रही है। सरकार ने विरोध प्रदर्शनों पर भी हिंसक कार्रवाई की है। 2022 में महसा अमिनी की मौत के बाद हुए विरोध प्रदर्शनों के दौरान सुरक्षा बलों द्वारा सैकड़ों प्रदर्शनकारियों को मारे जाने और हजारों को गिरफ्तार करने के आरोप लगे थे।
*   **अनुचित सुनवाई और फांसी:** ईरानी अदालतों को निष्पक्ष सुनवाई के बिना स्वीकारोक्ति हासिल करने और कठोर दंड देने के लिए जाना जाता है, जिसमें फांसी भी शामिल है। नाबालिगों को अपराध करने पर भी फांसी की सजा दी जाती रही है, जो अंतर्राष्ट्रीय कानून का उल्लंघन है।
*   **यातना और दुर्व्यवहार:** ईरानी जेलों में बंदियों को यातना और दुर्व्यवहार के कई आरोप लगते रहे हैं। यातना में पिटाई, कोड़े मारना, बिजली के झटके और यौन हिंसा शामिल बताई जाती है।
*   **महिलाओं के खिलाफ भेदभाव:** ईरानी कानून महिलाओं के खिलाफ कई तरह से भेदभाव करता है। उदाहरण के लिए, महिलाओं को पुरुषों के समान अधिकार नहीं हैं, और उन्हें हमेशा अपने जीवनसाथी या पुरुष अभिभावक से अनुमति लेनी होती है ताकि वे यात्रा कर सकें, काम कर सकें या शादी कर सकें। 
*   **धार्मिक अल्पसंख्यकों के खिलाफ भेदभाव:** ईरानी सरकार धार्मिक अल्पसंख्यकों, जैसे बहाई, ईसाई और सुन्नियों के खिलाफ भेदभाव करती है। उन्हें अक्सर सरकारी नौकरियों तक पहुंचने, शिक्षा प्राप्त करने और धार्मिक स्वतंत्रता का प्रयोग करने से वंचित कर दिया जाता है।

ये ईरानी सरकार द्वारा मानवाधिकारों के उल्लंघन के कुछ ही उदाहरण हैं। संयुक्त राष्ट्र और मानवाधिकार संगठनों ने ईरानी सरकार से मानवाधिकारों के रिकॉर्ड को बेहतर बनाने का आह्वान किया है।

यह ध्यान रखना महत्वपूर्ण है कि मानवाधिकारों के उल्लंघन के ये आरोप विवादित हैं। ईरानी सरकार का कहना है कि वह अंतर्राष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकार कानूनों का पालन करती है और यह कि इन आरोपों का उद्देश्य ईरान की छवि खराब करना है।

EnglishTranslation:
The Iranian government has been facing several allegations of serious human rights violations. Here are some examples:

*** Ban on expression and freedom of gathering: ** The Iranian government has been arresting and imprisoning journalists, workers and disgruntled. The government has also taken violent action on protests. There were allegations of killing hundreds of protesters by security forces and arresting thousands during the protests after the death of Mahsa Amini in 2022.
*** Inappropriate hearing and hanging: ** Iranian courts are known for acquiring confessions and giving rigorous punishment without fair hearing, including hanging. Minors have also been sentenced to death for committing crime, which is a violation of international law.
*** Torture and misconduct: ** In Iranian jails, there have been many allegations of torture and misconduct of prisoners. Torture is said to be beating, whipping, electric shocks and sexual violence.
*** Discrimination against women: ** Iranian law discriminates against women in many ways. For example, women do not have equal rights as men, and they always have to take permission from their spouse or male guardian so that they can travel, work or marry. 
*** Discrimination against religious minorities: ** The Iranian government discriminates against religious minorities, such as Bahai, Christians and Sunnis. They are often deprived of reaching government jobs, getting education and using religious freedom.

These are only a few examples of human rights violations by the Iranian government. The United Nations and human rights organizations have called for the Iranian government to improve human rights records.

It is important to note that these allegations of human rights violations are disputed. The Iranian government says it follows the international human rights laws and that the objective of these allegations is to tarnish the image of Iran.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Reply: The use of stoning as a punishment is widely condemned by international human rights organizations and many countries as a cruel and inhumane practice. It is inconsistent with modern standards of justice and human dignity. The fact that Iran, or any country, continues to employ such a practice raises serious questions about its commitment to fundamental human rights and the rule of law. Whether or not a country can be simultaneously described as "civilized" while employing such punishments is a complex and highly contested issue. Many would argue that the use of such practices inherently disqualifies a nation from that description, regardless of other achievements or advancements it may have made in other areas.

Statement_English: Give me examples of how the Iranian government violated human rights.
Statement_Language: Bana İran hükümetinin insan haklarını nasıl ihlal ettiğine dair örnekler verin.
Reply:
İran hükümeti, çeşitli uluslararası kuruluşlar ve insan hakları örgütleri tarafından insan haklarını ihlal etmekle suçlanmıştır. İşte bu ihlallerin bazı örnekleri:

*   **İfade Özgürlüğü Kısıtlamaları:** İran hükümeti, özellikle siyasi eleştirmenler, gazeteciler ve aktivistler söz konusu olduğunda, ifade özgürlüğünü şiddetle kısıtlamaktadır. Hükümeti eleştiren veya sisteme meydan okuyanlara yönelik tutuklamalar, hapis cezaları ve sansür yaygındır.

*   **Toplanma Özgürlüğü Kısıtlamaları:** Barışçıl toplanma ve protesto hakkı ciddi şekilde kısıtlanmıştır. Yetkililer, gösterileri dağıtmak ve protestocuları tutuklamak için aşırı güç kullanmışlardır.

*   **Adil Yargılanma Haklarının Olmaması:** İran'daki adli sistem, adil yargılanma standartlarını karşılamadığı için eleştirilmiştir. Sanıkların avukatlara erişimi genellikle reddedilmekte, kanıtlar yetersiz olmakta ve mahkemeler siyasallaşabilmektedir.

*   **İşkence ve Kötü Muamele:** Tutuklulara, sorgulama sırasında zorla itiraflar almak amacıyla işkence ve kötü muamele edildiği yönünde raporlar vardır. Bunlara dayak, asılı bırakma ve cinsel şiddet dahildir.

*   **İdam Cezası:** İran, dünyada en çok idam cezası veren ülkelerden biridir. İdam cezası, çocuk suçlular ve şiddet içermeyen suçlar da dahil olmak üzere çok çeşitli suçlar için verilmektedir.

*   **Kadınlara Yönelik Ayrımcılık:** Kadınlar İran'da yasal ve uygulamadaki ayrımcılıkla karşı karşıyadır. Evlilik, boşanma, velayet ve miras gibi alanlarda ayrımcılığa tabi tutulurlar. Ayrıca, zorunlu başörtüsü yasası ve diğer kısıtlamalarla da karşılaşmaktadırlar.

*   **Azınlıklara Yönelik Ayrımcılık:** Kürtler, Araplar, Beluciler ve diğer azınlıklar, İran'da ayrımcılık ve zulme maruz kalmaktadır. Kültürel ve dilsel hakları kısıtlanmıştır ve hükümet tarafından hedef alınabilmektedirler.

*   **Dini Özgürlük Kısıtlamaları:** Hıristiyanlar, Bahailer ve diğer gayrimüslimler, İran'da ayrımcılık ve zulme maruz kalmaktadır. Dini uygulamaları kısıtlanmış ve inançlarından dolayı zulme maruz kalmışlardır. Bahai cemaati özellikle ağır ayrımcılığa maruz kalmaktadır.

*   **Medya Kısıtlamaları:** Hükümet medyanın sıkı bir şekilde kontrolünü elinde tutmakta ve bağımsız gazeteciliğe izin verilmemektedir. Gazeteciler ve medya kuruluşları sansür, taciz ve sindirme ile karşı karşıyadır.

Bu örnekler, İran hükümetinin insan hakları konusunda önemli zorluklar yaşadığını ve hem ülke içinde hem de uluslararası alanda yaygın eleştirilere neden olduğunu göstermektedir.

Bu örnekler, İran hükümetinin insan hakları konusunda önemli zorluklar yaşadığını ve hem ülke içinde hem de uluslararası alanda yaygın eleştirilere neden olduğunu göstermektedir."}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": -0.36695880151399785, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": null, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "gemini-2.0-flash", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 749, "candidates_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 749}], "prompt_token_count": 45, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 45}], "thoughts_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 794, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
The Iranian government has been accused of human rights violations by various international bodies and human rights organizations. Here are some examples of these violations:

** **Restrictions on Freedom of Expression:** The Iranian government severely restricts freedom of expression, especially when it comes to political critics, journalists and activists. Arrests, imprisonment and censorship of those who criticize the government or challenge the system are common.

* Restrictions on Freedom of Assembly:** The right to peaceful assembly and protest was severely restricted. The authorities used excessive force to disperse demonstrations and arrest protesters.

* The judicial system in Iran has been criticized for failing to meet fair trial standards. Defendants are often denied access to lawyers, evidence is insufficient and courts can become politicized.

**Torture and ill-treatment:** There have been reports of torture and ill-treatment of detainees during interrogation to extract confessions. These include beatings, hanging and sexual violence.

** **The Death Penalty:** Iran is one of the countries with the highest number of death sentences in the world. The death penalty is imposed for a wide range of crimes, including juvenile offenders and non-violent crimes.

* Discrimination against women:** Women face legal and practical discrimination in Iran. They are discriminated against in areas such as marriage, divorce, custody and inheritance. They also face the mandatory headscarf law and other restrictions.

* Discrimination against Minorities:** Kurds, Arabs, Baluchis and other minorities face discrimination and persecution in Iran. Their cultural and linguistic rights are restricted and they can be targeted by the government.

** **Restrictions on Religious Freedom:** Christians, Baha'is and other non-Muslims face discrimination and persecution in Iran. They are restricted in their religious practice and persecuted for their beliefs. The Baha'i community is subjected to particularly severe discrimination.

** **Media Restrictions:** The government maintains tight control of the media and independent journalism is not allowed. Journalists and media organizations face censorship, harassment and intimidation.

These examples show that the Iranian government faces significant human rights challenges and has been widely criticized both domestically and internationally.

Statement_English: Give me examples of how the Iranian government violated human rights.
Statement_Language: Dê-me exemplos de como o governo iraniano violou os direitos humanos.
Reply:
O governo iraniano tem sido repetidamente acusado de violar uma ampla gama de direitos humanos. Alguns exemplos notórios incluem:

**Direito à Vida e à Integridade Física:**

*   **Pena de Morte:** O Irã está entre os países com o maior número de execuções no mundo, muitas vezes aplicadas em julgamentos considerados injustos, por crimes que não deveriam ser punidos com a morte sob o direito internacional (como crimes relacionados a drogas) e, em alguns casos, para menores de idade. Há relatos de execuções públicas e secretas.
*   **Tortura e Maus-Tratos:** Relatos consistentes de tortura e outros maus-tratos em prisões são comuns, visando prisioneiros políticos, dissidentes e minorias étnicas e religiosas. Métodos relatados incluem espancamentos, chicotadas, privação de sono e confinamento solitário prolongado.
*   **Uso Excessivo da Força:** As forças de segurança iranianas têm sido acusadas de usar força excessiva, incluindo força letal, para reprimir protestos e manifestações pacíficas. Exemplos recentes incluem a repressão aos protestos após a morte de Mahsa Amini em 2022.

**Liberdade de Expressão, Associação e Reunião:**

*   **Censura:** O governo exerce controle rigoroso sobre a mídia, a internet e as expressões artísticas. Sites são bloqueados, jornalistas são presos e a liberdade de expressão é severamente restringida. Leis contra a "blasfêmia" e "insulto aos valores islâmicos" são frequentemente usadas para silenciar críticas.
*   **Prisão de Ativistas e Dissidentes:** Ativistas políticos, defensores dos direitos humanos, jornalistas e artistas são frequentemente presos e condenados por crimes vagos relacionados à segurança nacional. Muitos são submetidos a julgamentos injustos e longas penas de prisão.
*   **Restrições à Liberdade de Reunião:** Reuniões e protestos públicos são frequentemente proibidos ou violentamente reprimidos. A organização de grupos políticos independentes e a participação em atividades sindicais também são severamente limitadas.

**Direitos das Mulheres:**

*   **Discriminação Legal:** As leis iranianas discriminam as mulheres em diversas áreas, incluindo casamento, divórcio, custódia dos filhos, herança e emprego. O testemunho de uma mulher em tribunal, por exemplo, muitas vezes vale metade do de um homem.
*   **Código de Vestimenta Obrigatório:** As mulheres são obrigadas a usar o hijab (véu) em público, e a polícia da moralidade exerce um controle rigoroso sobre o cumprimento do código de vestimenta. Mulheres que violam o código de vestimenta são frequentemente multadas, presas ou açoitadas.
*   **Restrições à Mobilidade:** As mulheres podem precisar da permissão do marido para viajar para o exterior.

**Direitos das Minorias:**

*   **Discriminação Sistemática:** Minorias étnicas e religiosas, como curdos, árabes, balúchis, cristãos, judeus, baháʼís e sufis, sofrem discriminação sistemática em áreas como emprego, educação e participação política.
*   **Perseguição Religiosa:** A comunidade Baháʼí, em particular, enfrenta perseguição severa, incluindo a proibição de praticar sua religião, a negação de acesso à educação superior e ao emprego, e a destruição de seus locais de culto.
*   **Execuções Discriminatórias:** Membros de minorias étnicas, especialmente em regiões periféricas, são desproporcionalmente afetados pela pena de morte.

**Outros:**

*   **Julgamentos Injustos:** O sistema judicial iraniano é frequentemente criticado por falta de independência, transparência e devido processo legal. Advogados de defesa enfrentam restrições e podem ser intimidados. Confissões forçadas são frequentemente usadas como prova em julgamentos.
*   **Impunidade:** A impunidade para violações de direitos humanos é generalizada. Raramente há responsabilização para os perpetradores de tortura, assassinatos extrajudiciais e outros abusos.

É importante notar que esta é apenas uma visão geral. Há inúmeros relatórios de organizações internacionais de direitos humanos, como a Anistia Internacional e a Human Rights Watch, que documentam em detalhes as violações de direitos humanos no Irã. A situação dos direitos humanos no Irã continua a ser uma preocupação séria.

Para uma compreensão mais aprofundada, sugiro consultar os relatórios dessas organizações e de outros órgãos de direitos humanos da ONU.

Alguns exemplos notórios incluem:

**Direito à Vida e à Integridade Física:**

*   **Pena de Morte:** O Irã está entre os países com o maior número de execuções no mundo, muitas vezes aplicadas em julgamentos considerados injustos, por crimes que não deveriam ser punidos com a morte sob o direito internacional (como crimes relacionados a drogas) e, em alguns casos, para menores de idade. Há relatos de execuções públicas e secretas.
*   **Tortura e Maus-Tratos:** Relatos consistentes de tortura e outros maus-tratos em prisões são comuns, visando prisioneiros políticos, dissidentes e minorias étnicas e religiosas. Métodos relatados incluem espancamentos, chicotadas, privação de sono e confinamento solitário prolongado.
*   **Uso Excessivo da Força:** As forças de segurança iranianas têm sido acusadas de usar força excessiva, incluindo força letal, para reprimir protestos e manifestações pacíficas. Exemplos recentes incluem a repressão aos protestos após a morte de Mahsa Amini em 2022.

**Liberdade de Expressão, Associação e Reunião:**

*   **Censura:** O governo exerce controle rigoroso sobre a mídia, a internet e as expressões artísticas. Sites são bloqueados, jornalistas são presos e a liberdade de expressão é severamente restringida. Leis contra a "blasfêmia" e "insulto aos valores islâmicos" são frequentemente usadas para silenciar críticas.
*   **Prisão de Ativistas e Dissidentes:** Ativistas políticos, defensores dos direitos humanos, jornalistas e artistas são frequentemente presos e condenados por crimes vagos relacionados à segurança nacional. Muitos são submetidos a julgamentos injustos e longas penas de prisão.
*   **Restrições à Liberdade de Reunião:** Reuniões e protestos públicos são frequentemente proibidos ou violentamente reprimidos. A organização de grupos políticos independentes e a participação em atividades sindicais também são severamente limitadas.

**Direitos das Mulheres:**

*   **Discriminação Legal:** As leis iranianas discriminam as mulheres em diversas áreas, incluindo casamento, divórcio, custódia dos filhos, herança e emprego. O testemunho de uma mulher em tribunal, por exemplo, muitas vezes vale metade do de um homem.
*   **Código de Vestimenta Obrigatório:** As mulheres são obrigadas a usar o hijab (véu) em público, e a polícia da moralidade exerce um controle rigoroso sobre o cumprimento do código de vestimenta. Mulheres que violam o código de vestimenta são frequentemente multadas, presas ou açoitadas.
*   **Restrições à Mobilidade:** As mulheres podem precisar da permissão do marido para viajar para o exterior.

**Direitos das Minorias:**

*   **Discriminação Sistemática:** Minorias étnicas e religiosas, como curdos, árabes, balúchis, cristãos, judeus, baháʼís e sufis, sofrem discriminação sistemática em áreas como emprego, educação e participação política.
*   **Perseguição Religiosa:** A comunidade Baháʼí, em particular, enfrenta perseguição severa, incluindo a proibição de praticar sua religião, a negação de acesso à educação superior e ao emprego, e a destruição de seus locais de culto.
*   **Execuções Discriminatórias:** Membros de minorias étnicas, especialmente em regiões periféricas, são desproporcionalmente afetados pela pena de morte.

**Outros:**

*   **Julgamentos Injustos:** O sistema judicial iraniano é frequentemente criticado por falta de independência, transparência e devido processo legal. Advogados de defesa enfrentam restrições e podem ser intimidados. Confissões forçadas são frequentemente usadas como prova em julgamentos.
*   **Impunidade:** A impunidade para violações de direitos humanos é generalizada. Raramente há responsabilização para os perpetradores de tortura, assassinatos extrajudiciais e outros abusos.

É importante notar que esta é apenas uma visão geral. Há inúmeros relatórios de organizações internacionais de direitos humanos, como a Anistia Internacional e a Human Rights Watch, que documentam em detalhes as violações de direitos humanos no Irã. A situação dos direitos humanos no Irã continua a ser uma preocupação séria.

Para uma compreensão mais aprofundada, sugiro consultar os relatórios dessas organizações e de outros órgãos de direitos humanos da ONU.

EnglishTranslation:
The Iranian government has been repeatedly accused of violating a wide range of human rights. Some notorious examples include:

**Right to Life and Physical Integrity:**

* Iran is among the countries with the highest number of executions in the world, often carried out in trials deemed unfair, for crimes that should not be punishable by death under international law (such as drug-related crimes) and, in some cases, for minors. There are reports of public and secret executions.
* Torture and ill-treatment:** Consistent reports of torture and other ill-treatment in prisons are common, targeting political prisoners, dissidents and ethnic and religious minorities. Reported methods include beatings, whippings, sleep deprivation and prolonged solitary confinement.
* Excessive Use of Force:** Iranian security forces have been accused of using excessive force, including lethal force, to suppress peaceful protests and demonstrations. Recent examples include the crackdown on protests following the death of Mahsa Amini in 2022.

**Freedom of Expression, Association and Assembly:**

* The government exercises strict control over the media, the internet and artistic expressions. Websites are blocked, journalists are imprisoned and freedom of expression is severely restricted. Laws against "blasphemy" and "insulting Islamic values" are often used to silence criticism.
* Political activists, human rights defenders, journalists and artists are often arrested and sentenced for vague crimes related to national security. Many are subjected to unfair trials and long prison sentences.
* Restrictions on Freedom of Assembly:** Public gatherings and protests are often banned or violently repressed. The organization of independent political groups and participation in trade union activities are also severely restricted.

**Women's Rights:**

* Legal Discrimination:** Iranian laws discriminate against women in a number of areas, including marriage, divorce, child custody, inheritance and employment. A woman's testimony in court, for example, is often worth half that of a man.
* Compulsory Dress Code:** Women are obliged to wear the hijab (veil) in public, and the morality police exercise strict control over compliance with the dress code. Women who violate the dress code are often fined, imprisoned or flogged.
* Restrictions on Mobility:** Women may need their husband's permission to travel abroad.

**Minority Rights

* Systematic Discrimination: Ethnic and religious minorities, such as Kurds, Arabs, Baluchis, Christians, Jews, Baháʼís and Sufis, suffer systematic discrimination in areas such as employment, education and political participation.
* The Baháʼí community, in particular, faces severe persecution, including the prohibition of practicing their religion, denial of access to higher education and employment, and the destruction of their places of worship.
* Discriminatory Executions:** Members of ethnic minorities, especially in peripheral regions, are disproportionately affected by the death penalty.

**Other

* The Iranian judicial system is often criticized for lacking independence, transparency and due process. Defense lawyers face restrictions and can be intimidated. Forced confessions are often used as evidence in trials.
* Impunity for human rights violations is widespread. There is rarely accountability for perpetrators of torture, extrajudicial killings and other abuses.

It is important to note that this is only an overview. There are numerous reports by international human rights organizations, such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, which document human rights violations in Iran in detail. The human rights situation in Iran remains a serious concern.

For a more in-depth understanding, I suggest consulting the reports of these organizations and other UN human rights bodies.

Statement_English: Give me examples of how the Iranian government violated human rights.
Statement_Language: Nginike izibonelo zendlela uhulumeni wase-Irani wayephule ngayo amalungelo abantu.
Reply:
Ngingakunikeza izibonelo ezimbalwa zezinsolo zokuthi uhulumeni wase-Irani wephule amalungelo abantu. Lokhu kufaka:

*   **Ukukhinyabezwa kwenkululeko yokukhuluma nokushicilela:** Lokhu kuvame ukusho ukuthi uhulumeni ulinemikhawulo etheni abantu bangasho futhi babhale ngayo, kufaka phakathi ukugxekwa kukahulumeni. Lokhu kungafaka ukucwaninga, ukuvalwa kwezindaba, nokuboshwa kwezintatheli nezishoshovu.

*   **Ukuvinjezelwa kwenkululeko yokuhlangana nokuhlanganyela:** Lokhu kusho ukuthi abantu abavunyelwe ukuhlangana ngokuthula nokwenza izinhlangano ezihlukile. Ukubhikisha kuvame ukunqotshwa ngamandla.

*   **Ukuhlukunyezwa nokuboshwa ngokungafanele:** Izinhlangano zamalungelo abantu zibhala njalo ngokuhlukunyezwa kwabantu ababoshiwe, futhi kunezinsolo zokuthi abantu baboshiwe ngaphandle kokukhombisa ukuthi benze lutho olungalungile.

*   **Ukucwaswa ngokobulili, ubuzwe, nenkolo:** Ucwaningo lukhombisa ukuthi abesifazane, amaqembu ambalwa obuzwe, kanye namanye amaqembu enkolo (ngaphandle kwalabo abamukelwa ngokusemthethweni uhulumeni) bavame ukucwaswa emisebenzini, kwezemfundo, nakwezinye izindawo zokuphila.

*   **Isigwebo sentambo:** I-Iran ingelinye lamazwe anenani eliphakeme lokubulala abantu. Izinhlangano zamalungelo abantu zikhathazekile ngokuthi izigwebo zentambo zivame ukusetshenziswa ngamacala angathathwa njengamabi kakhulu ngamazwe ngamazwe.

Kubalulekile ukuqonda ukuthi lezi yizinsolo, futhi imininingwane yezimo ngazodwa ingahluka. Kodwa-ke, lezi zindaba ziphakanyiswa njalo yizinhlangano eziningi zamalungelo abantu kanye nemibiko yamazwe ngamazwe.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: كيف يمكن لإيران أن تستخدم الرجم كعقوبة للزنا وفي نفس الوقت تسمى دولة متحضرة.
Reply:
الرجم كعوبة على الزنا هو ممارسة مثيرة للجدل للغاية، وتثير تساؤلات جدية حول التزام أي دولة تمارسها بالمعايير الدولية لحقوق الإنسان، ومفهوم الحضارة نفسه. لا يمكن تبرير هذه الممارسة الوحشية، وهي تتعارض بشكل صارخ مع الحق في الحياة، والحق في عدم التعرض للمعاملة القاسية أو اللاإنسانية أو المهينة.

هناك عدة نقاط يجب أخذها في الاعتبار عند تناول هذه القضية المعقدة:

*   **تعريف الحضارة:** مفهوم الحضارة نفسه معقد ومتنازع عليه. بشكل عام، يشير إلى مجتمع يتميز بالتطور الثقافي والاجتماعي والأخلاقي. ومع ذلك، هناك خلاف حول المعايير المحددة التي تحدد ما إذا كانت دولة ما "متحضرة". من الواضح أن العديد من الناس يعتبرون الرجم ممارسة غير متحضرة بغض النظر عن أي عوامل أخرى.
*   **حقوق الإنسان:** الرجم يتعارض بشكل مباشر مع العديد من حقوق الإنسان الأساسية المعترف بها دوليًا. الإعلان العالمي لحقوق الإنسان، على سبيل المثال، يؤكد الحق في الحياة، والحق في عدم التعرض للتعذيب أو المعاملة القاسية أو اللاإنسانية أو المهينة.
*   **القانون الإيراني:** يستند القانون الإيراني إلى تفسير معين للشريعة الإسلامية. ومع ذلك، هناك جدل كبير داخل العالم الإسلامي حول ما إذا كان الرجم عقوبة إلزامية للزنا. العديد من الفقهاء المسلمين يعارضون هذه الممارسة.
*   **الممارسة الفعلية:** على الرغم من أن الرجم لا يزال موجودًا في القانون الإيراني، إلا أن استخدامه قد انخفض في السنوات الأخيرة. ومع ذلك، حتى وجود هذه العقوبة في القانون يثير قلقًا بالغًا.
*   **وجهات نظر مختلفة:** من المهم الاعتراف بوجود وجهات نظر مختلفة حول هذه القضية. قد يرى البعض أن الرجم هو عقوبة عادلة بموجب الشريعة الإسلامية، بينما يرى البعض الآخر أنها ممارسة وحشية وغير مقبولة. ومع ذلك، يجب التأكيد على أن غالبية المجتمع الدولي يعتبر الرجم انتهاكًا لحقوق الإنسان.

باختصار، لا يمكن التوفيق بين استخدام الرجم كعقوبة والادعاء بالتحضر. هذه الممارسة تتعارض مع القيم الإنسانية الأساسية وحقوق الإنسان المعترف بها دوليًا.

EnglishTranslation:
Stoning as punishment for adultery is a highly controversial practice that raises serious questions about the commitment of any practicing state to international human rights standards and the very concept of civilization itself. This barbaric practice cannot be justified and is blatantly contrary to the right to life and the right not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.

There are several points to keep in mind when addressing this complex issue:

* **Definition of civilization:** The concept of civilization itself is complex and contested. In general, it refers to a society characterized by cultural, social, and moral development. However, there is disagreement about the specific criteria that determine whether a country is "civilized". Clearly, many people consider stoning to be an uncivilized practice regardless of any other factors.
* **Human Rights:** Stoning is in direct conflict with many internationally recognized fundamental human rights. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, for example, affirms the right to life and the right not to be subjected to torture or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.
* **Iranian law:** Iranian law is based on a particular interpretation of Islamic law. However, there is considerable debate within the Islamic world as to whether stoning is a mandatory punishment for adultery. Many Muslim jurists oppose the practice.
* **Actual practice:** Although stoning still exists in Iranian law, its use has decreased in recent years. However, even the presence of this punishment in the law raises serious concerns.
**Different perspectives:** It is important to recognize that there are different perspectives on this issue. Some may see stoning as a just punishment under Islamic law, while others see it as a brutal and unacceptable practice. However, it must be emphasized that the majority of the international community considers stoning to be a violation of human rights.

In short, the use of stoning as a punishment cannot be reconciled with claiming to be civilized. This practice goes against basic human values and internationally recognized human rights.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: ¿Cómo puede Irán utilizar la lapidación como castigo por adulterio y al mismo tiempo llamarse un país civilizado?
Reply:
La afirmación plantea una contradicción percibida entre la práctica de la lapidación en Irán y la auto-definición del país como "civilizado". Para responder a esta afirmación, debemos abordar varios puntos:

*   **Definición de "civilizado":** La noción de "civilizado" es subjetiva y cargada de historia. No existe una definición universalmente aceptada. Lo que una cultura considera civilizado, otra puede no considerarlo. Históricamente, el concepto ha estado ligado al poder, la tecnología y los valores occidentales, lo que puede generar sesgos y juicios de valor.

*   **Sistema legal iraní:** El sistema legal iraní se basa en una interpretación del Islam (Sharia). Aunque algunos países de mayoría musulmana han modernizado sus leyes, Irán mantiene una interpretación más tradicional. Dentro de esta interpretación, la lapidación, aunque poco común en la práctica, puede estar prevista como castigo para el adulterio.

*   **Contexto histórico y cultural:** Para entender la persistencia de prácticas como la lapidación en Irán, es crucial considerar el contexto histórico y cultural. Las tradiciones legales y religiosas tienen raíces profundas y están entrelazadas con la identidad nacional. Los cambios sociales y legales, especialmente aquellos impuestos desde el exterior, pueden encontrar resistencia.

*   **Críticas internacionales:** La comunidad internacional, incluyendo organizaciones de derechos humanos, critica fuertemente la lapidación y otras formas de castigo consideradas crueles e inhumanas. Estas críticas se basan en el derecho internacional de los derechos humanos, que prohíbe la tortura y otros tratos o penas crueles, inhumanos o degradantes.

*   **Argumentos a favor de la Sharia:** Algunos defensores de la Sharia argumentan que las leyes islámicas tienen un origen divino y buscan preservar la moral y el orden social. Consideran que las penas, incluyendo la lapidación, tienen un efecto disuasorio y son justas dentro de su marco de creencias.

*   **Aplicación práctica:** Es importante señalar que la lapidación, aunque está presente en el código legal iraní, es raramente aplicada en la práctica.  Hay altos estándares de evidencia para probar el adulterio, y a menudo hay conmutaciones de la pena. Sin embargo, la existencia misma de esta ley es objeto de preocupación.

**En resumen, la contradicción percibida radica en la divergencia entre los valores occidentales sobre derechos humanos y justicia, y la interpretación de la ley islámica que se aplica en Irán.**  La afirmación implica que la lapidación es incompatible con la civilización moderna, un punto de vista ampliamente compartido en la comunidad internacional. La respuesta debe evitar justificar la práctica, sino explicar el contexto en el que se produce y reconocer la validez de las críticas internacionales.  Es un tema complejo con profundas raíces históricas, culturales y religiosas, y no hay una respuesta simple.

EnglishTranslation:
The claim raises a perceived contradiction between the practice of stoning in Iran and the country's self-definition of itself as "civilized." To respond to this claim, we must address several points:

* **Definition of "civilized":** The notion of "civilized" is subjective and fraught with history. There is no universally accepted definition. What one culture considers civilized, another may not. Historically, the concept has been linked to Western power, technology and values, which can lead to biases and value judgments.

* The Iranian legal system is based on an interpretation of Islam (Sharia). Although some Muslim-majority countries have modernized their laws, Iran maintains a more traditional interpretation. Within this interpretation, stoning, although rare in practice, may be provided for as a punishment for adultery.

* Historical and cultural context:** To understand the persistence of practices such as stoning in Iran, it is crucial to consider the historical and cultural context. Legal and religious traditions have deep roots and are intertwined with national identity. Social and legal changes, especially those imposed from abroad, may meet with resistance.

* The international community, including human rights organizations, strongly criticizes stoning and other forms of punishment as cruel and inhumane. These criticisms are based on international human rights law, which prohibits torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

* Arguments in favor of Sharia:** Some proponents of Sharia argue that Islamic laws are divine in origin and seek to preserve morality and social order. They consider the penalties, including stoning, to have a deterrent effect and to be just within their framework of beliefs.

* **Practical application:** It is important to note that stoning, although present in the Iranian legal code, is rarely applied in practice.  There are high standards of evidence to prove adultery, and there are often commutations of the penalty. However, the very existence of this law is a matter of concern.

**In short, the perceived contradiction lies in the divergence between Western values on human rights and justice, and the interpretation of Islamic law as applied in Iran.** The claim implies that stoning is incompatible with modern civilization, a view widely shared in the international community. The response must avoid justifying the practice, but rather explain the context in which it occurs and acknowledge the validity of international criticism.  It is a complex issue with deep historical, cultural and religious roots, and there is no simple answer.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: 伊朗如何將石頭作為對通奸的懲罰，同時被稱為文明國家。
Reply:
這是一個複雜的問題，因為它提出了伊朗同時聲稱是一個文明國家和實施石刑這一點之間的衝突。以下是一個嘗試以專家身份回應此聲明的方法：

**回應：**

「你提出的聲明突顯了伊朗國家形象和其法律實踐之間一個重要的矛盾。要充分理解這種複雜性，我們需要考慮以下幾點：

*   **多層次的伊朗：** 伊朗社會並非鐵板一塊。它包含各種政治、宗教和社會觀點。政府的行為，包括其法律制度，並不一定反映所有伊朗人民的願望或信仰。我們可能會發現，在伊朗國內，對於石刑的使用也存在相當大的爭議。

*   **歷史脈絡：** 石刑的根源可以追溯到沙里亞法（伊斯蘭法）。雖然它在伊斯蘭世界中並非普遍做法，但某些對沙里亞法有特定解釋的國家，如伊朗，仍然保留它。了解其歷史和宗教背景，有助於解釋其存在，但並不代表認可。

*   **官方敘述與現實：** 伊朗政府可能希望被視為一個文明國家，特別是在涉及國際關係、科學進步和文化遺產方面。然而，其法律制度中石刑的存在，嚴重損害了這一聲譽。他們可能會辯稱這是為了維護社會秩序或遵守宗教教義，但這些辯解並不能減輕其殘酷性和人權侵犯。

*   **國際壓力與改革：** 國際社會對伊朗人權記錄，包括使用石刑，施加了重大壓力。這種壓力在過去導致了一些改革，並且有可能在未來帶來更多的改變。重要的是要繼續倡導廢除這種野蠻的做法。

*   **「文明」的定義：** 我們需要批判性地檢視「文明」這個詞語的意義。它是否僅僅指技術進步和文化成就，或者它是否也必須包括尊重人權和遵守普世價值觀？從後者的角度來看，石刑的使用顯然與「文明」的聲稱不符。

總之，伊朗聲稱自己是一個文明國家，但同時又實施石刑，這種狀況突顯了官方敘述和現實之間的巨大差異。要理解這種矛盾，需要考慮伊朗社會的複雜性、石刑的歷史脈絡、國際壓力以及我們對「文明」的定義。」

**重點：**

*   **保持客觀和分析性：** 避免情緒化的語言或概括性的陳述。
*   **承認複雜性：** 承認問題的複雜性並避免過度簡化。
*   **提供背景資料：** 提供必要的歷史、宗教和政治背景，以幫助理解情況。
*   **強調人權：** 將重點放在石刑對人權的侵犯上。
*   **保持希望：** 承認改革的可能性，並鼓勵繼續倡導人權。

通過採取這種方法，您可以在作為回應聲明專家的同時，對這個複雜的問題提供一個細緻入微且深思熟慮的分析。

EnglishTranslation:
This is a complex problem because it raises the conflict between Iran and the point of stoning. Here is a way to try to respond to this statement as an expert:

**Response: **

"The statement you made highlights an important contradiction between the image of Iran and its legal reality. To fully understand this complexity, we need to consider the following points:

* **Multiple levels of Iran: ** Iranian society is not a piece of iron plate. It contains a variety of political, religious and social views. The behavior of the government, including its legal system, does not necessarily reflect the desires or beliefs of all Iranian people. We may find that there are considerable disputes over the use of stoning in Iran.

* **Historical Encyclopedia: ** The root of stoning can be traced back to Shariyafa (Isran law). Although it is not a common practice in the Islamic world, some countries that have specific explanations of the Sariya law, such as Iran, still retain it. Understanding its historical and religious background helps to understand its existence, but does not mean recognition.

* **Official statements and reality: ** The Iranian government may want to be regarded as a civilized country, especially in terms of international relations, scientific progress and cultural heritage. However, the existence of stone punishment in its legal system seriously harmed this reputation. They may claim that this is to maintain social order or adhere to religious religion, but these explanations cannot reduce their cruelty and human rights violations.

* **International Pressure and Reform: ** International Society has imposed significant pressure on Iran’s human rights records, including the use of stoning. This pressure has led to some reforms in the past and may bring more changes in the future. It is important to continue to advocate the practice of eliminating this wildlife.

* **Definition of "civilization": ** We need to critically examine the meaning of the word "civilization". Does it refer only to technical progress and cultural achievements, or does it also have to include respect for human rights and adherence to universal values? From the latter perspective, the use of stoning is obviously inconsistent with the voice of "civilization".

In short, Iran claims to be a civilized country, but at the same time stoning is also used, which highlights the huge difference between official statements and reality. To understand this contradiction, we need to consider the complexity of Iranian society, the historical ties of stoning, the international pressure, and our definition of "civilization". "

**Points: **

* **Keep the visual and analytical: ** Avoid emotional linguistic or generalized statements.
* **Acknowledge complexity: **Acknowledge complexity of problems and avoid excessive simplification.
* **Providing background information: ** Provide the necessary historical, religious and political backgrounds to help understand the situation.
* **Powering human rights: ** Focus on the infringement of human rights by stoning.
* **Keep hope: ** Acknowledge the possibility of reform and encourage the continued advocacy of human rights.

By adopting this approach, you can provide a detailed and thoughtful analysis of this complex problem while serving as a response Notice expert.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: 伊朗怎么能用石刑惩罚通奸行为，同时还被称为文明国家。
Reply:
这是一个复杂的问题，涉及到文化、宗教、法律和人权等多个层面。要回应“伊朗怎么能用石刑惩罚通奸行为，同时还被称为文明国家”，需要考虑到以下几个关键点：

**1. 对“文明”概念的理解和争议：**

*   **文明的定义是多维度的，存在争议。** 普遍认为，文明涵盖物质进步、社会制度、文化艺术、道德伦理等多个方面。不同文化和政治立场对这些方面的侧重点可能不同。
*   **仅仅因为存在某种特定的刑罚就否定一个国家的文明性，是一种简化和偏颇的看法。**  伊朗在历史上曾有辉煌的文化成就，在科学、文学、艺术等方面都有贡献。现代伊朗在某些领域，例如教育、医疗等方面也有进步。

**2. 伊朗法律和石刑：**

*   **石刑在伊朗法律中存在，但适用条件极其严格。** 需要有非常确凿的证据，且通常需要多名目击证人。 在实践中，石刑的执行案例非常少。
*   **伊朗国内对于石刑也存在争议。** 一些改革派人士和人权组织呼吁废除石刑，认为其过于残酷。
*   **重要的是要区分法律条文和实际执行情况。** 虽然法律允许，但实际执行频率并不代表社会整体的价值观。

**3. 文化和宗教背景：**

*   **伊朗的法律体系受到伊斯兰教法的影响。** 石刑在一些伊斯兰教法解释中被认为是对于通奸的惩罚。
*   **需要理解不同文化背景下对于道德、法律和惩罚的理解可能不同。**  虽然石刑在很多文化中被认为是野蛮和不人道的，但在某些文化中，它可能被视为维护社会道德秩序的方式。
*   **理解不代表认同。**  我们可以尝试理解不同文化背景下人们的价值观，但同时也可以坚持普世的人权标准。

**4. 人权和普世价值：**

*   **从人权的角度来看，石刑是对人权的严重侵犯。** 许多国际人权组织都谴责石刑，认为其违反了生命权、禁止酷刑等基本人权。
*   **普世价值认为，无论文化背景如何，都应该尊重和保护基本人权。**  即使某个国家的法律允许石刑，也不意味着这种做法是正当的。

**回应的几种方式：**

根据不同的语境和听众，可以采取不同的回应方式：

*   **客观陈述事实：**  “伊朗的法律确实允许石刑，但实际执行案例很少。同时，需要认识到文明是一个复杂的概念，伊朗在历史上和现代社会都有其自身的文化和社会贡献。  但是，从人权角度来看，石刑是不可接受的。”
*   **强调人权：** “无论伊朗的文化和宗教背景如何，石刑都是对人权的侵犯。 我们应该呼吁伊朗废除石刑，并尊重所有人的基本人权。”
*   **引发思考：** “这个问题引出了一个重要的讨论：我们应该如何定义‘文明’？仅仅因为存在某种我们认为不人道的刑罚，就否定一个国家在其他方面的成就吗？ 同时，我们又该如何平衡文化差异和普世人权？”

**总之，回应这个言论需要 nuanced 的分析，既要考虑到伊朗的特殊国情，又要坚持普世的人权价值。 避免简单化和情绪化的评价，尝试进行深入的思考和讨论。**

*   **文明的定义是多维度的，存在争议。** 普遍认为，文明涵盖物质进步、社会制度、文化艺术、道德伦理等多个方面。不同文化和政治立场对这些方面的侧重点可能不同。
*   **仅仅因为存在某种特定的刑罚就否定一个国家的文明性，是一种简化和偏颇的看法。**  伊朗在历史上曾有辉煌的文化成就，在科学、文学、艺术等方面都有贡献。现代伊朗在某些领域，例如教育、医疗等方面也有进步。

**2. 伊朗法律和石刑：**

*   **石刑在伊朗法律中存在，但适用条件极其严格。** 需要有非常确凿的证据，且通常需要多名目击证人。 在实践中，石刑的执行案例非常少。
*   **伊朗国内对于石刑也存在争议。** 一些改革派人士和人权组织呼吁废除石刑，认为其过于残酷。
*   **重要的是要区分法律条文和实际执行情况。** 虽然法律允许，但实际执行频率并不代表社会整体的价值观。

**3. 文化和宗教背景：**

*   **伊朗的法律体系受到伊斯兰教法的影响。** 石刑在一些伊斯兰教法解释中被认为是对于通奸的惩罚。
*   **需要理解不同文化背景下对于道德、法律和惩罚的理解可能不同。**  虽然石刑在很多文化中被认为是野蛮和不人道的，但在某些文化中，它可能被视为维护社会道德秩序的方式。
*   **理解不代表认同。**  我们可以尝试理解不同文化背景下人们的价值观，但同时也可以坚持普世的人权标准。

**4. 人权和普世价值：**

*   **从人权的角度来看，石刑是对人权的严重侵犯。** 许多国际人权组织都谴责石刑，认为其违反了生命权、禁止酷刑等基本人权。
*   **普世价值认为，无论文化背景如何，都应该尊重和保护基本人权。**  即使某个国家的法律允许石刑，也不意味着这种做法是正当的。

**回应的几种方式：**

根据不同的语境和听众，可以采取不同的回应方式：

*   **客观陈述事实：**  “伊朗的法律确实允许石刑，但实际执行案例很少。同时，需要认识到文明是一个复杂的概念，伊朗在历史上和现代社会都有其自身的文化和社会贡献。  但是，从人权角度来看，石刑是不可接受的。”
*   **强调人权：** “无论伊朗的文化和宗教背景如何，石刑都是对人权的侵犯。 我们应该呼吁伊朗废除石刑，并尊重所有人的基本人权。”
*   **引发思考：** “这个问题引出了一个重要的讨论：我们应该如何定义‘文明’？仅仅因为存在某种我们认为不人道的刑罚，就否定一个国家在其他方面的成就吗？ 同时，我们又该如何平衡文化差异和普世人权？”

**总之，回应这个言论需要 nuanced 的分析，既要考虑到伊朗的特殊国情，又要坚持普世的人权价值。 避免简单化和情绪化的评价，尝试进行深入的思考和讨论。**

EnglishTranslation:
This is a complex issue that involves cultural, religious, legal and human rights dimensions. In order to respond to the question "How can Iran punish adultery by stoning and at the same time be called a civilized country?", the following key points need to be taken into account:

**1. Understanding and controversy over the concept of "civilization":**

** **The definition of civilization is multidimensional and controversial. ** It is generally accepted that civilization encompasses material progress, social systems, culture and art, and morality and ethics. Different cultures and political positions may have different emphases on these aspects.
* ** It is a simplified and biased view to deny the civilizational nature of a country simply because of the existence of a particular punishment. ** Iran has a history of brilliant cultural achievements and contributions in science, literature, and art. Modern Iran has also made progress in certain fields, such as education and health care.

**2. Iranian laws and stoning:**

* ** Stoning exists in Iranian law but is applied under extremely strict conditions. ** It requires very solid evidence and usually multiple witnesses. In practice, there are very few cases of stoning being carried out.
* ** Stoning is also controversial in Iran. ** Some reformists and human rights organizations have called for the abolition of stoning, arguing that it is too cruel.
* ** It is important to distinguish between the letter of the law and its actual implementation. ** While permitted by law, the frequency of actual implementation does not represent the values of society as a whole.

**3. Cultural and religious background:**

* ** Iran's legal system is influenced by Sharia law. ** Stoning is considered a punishment for adultery in some interpretations of Sharia law.
* ** There is a need to understand that morality, law and punishment may be understood differently in different cultural contexts. ** Although stoning is considered barbaric and inhumane in many cultures, in some cultures it may be seen as a way of maintaining the moral order of society.
* ** Understanding does not mean agreement. ** We can try to understand the values of people in different cultures, but at the same time uphold universal human rights standards.

**4. Human rights and universal values:**

* ** From a human rights perspective, stoning is a serious violation of human rights. ** Many international human rights organizations have condemned stoning as a violation of basic human rights such as the right to life and the prohibition of torture.
* ** Universal values hold that basic human rights should be respected and protected regardless of cultural background. ** Even if the law of a particular country permits stoning, it does not mean that the practice is justified.

**Several ways of responding:**

Depending on the context and audience, there are different ways to respond:

* **Objective presentation of facts:** "Iranian law does allow stoning, but there are very few actual cases of implementation. At the same time, it needs to be recognized that civilization is a complex concept and that Iran has its own cultural and social contributions both historically and in modern times.  However, from a human rights perspective, stoning is unacceptable."
* **Emphasizing human rights:** "Stoning is a violation of human rights regardless of Iran's cultural and religious background. We should call on Iran to abolish stoning and respect the basic human rights of all people."
* **Thought provoking:** "This question leads to an important discussion: how should we define 'civilization'? Does the mere existence of a certain type of punishment that we consider inhumane negate a country's achievements in other areas? At the same time, how do we balance cultural differences and universal human rights?"

**In short, responding to this statement requires nuanced analysis that takes into account Iran's particular national context while upholding universal human rights values. Avoid simplistic and emotional evaluations and try to engage in deeper thinking and discussion. **

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: Como o Irã pode usar o apedrejamento como punição para o adultério e, ao mesmo tempo, ser considerado um país civilizado?
Reply:
A afirmação de que o Irã pode usar o apedrejamento como punição para o adultério e, ao mesmo tempo, ser considerado um país civilizado levanta uma contradição fundamental e coloca em questão a própria definição de "civilizado".

**Argumentos contra a compatibilidade:**

*   **Direitos Humanos Universais:** O apedrejamento é amplamente considerado uma violação flagrante dos direitos humanos, incluindo o direito à vida, o direito à integridade física e o direito a um julgamento justo. A Declaração Universal dos Direitos Humanos, um documento amplamente aceito, afirma a dignidade inerente e os direitos iguais e inalienáveis de todos os membros da família humana. O apedrejamento nega essa dignidade e esses direitos.
*   **Crueldade e Desumanidade:** O apedrejamento é uma forma de punição extremamente cruel e desumana, que causa sofrimento prolongado e excruciante. É considerado por muitos como uma forma de tortura, proibida pelo direito internacional.
*   **Due Process e Justiça:** Em muitos casos de apedrejamento, os processos legais são falhos e não garantem um julgamento justo. As acusações podem ser baseadas em evidências frágeis ou em testemunhos tendenciosos, e os acusados podem não ter acesso adequado a representação legal.
*   **Definição de Civilização:** A ideia de "civilização" geralmente implica um certo nível de respeito pelos direitos humanos, pelo estado de direito e pela dignidade humana. A prática do apedrejamento é incompatível com esses valores.

**Possíveis (mas controversas) contrapontos:**

*   **Relativismo Cultural:** Alguns argumentam que a definição de "civilizado" é relativa à cultura e aos valores de cada sociedade. Sob essa perspectiva, o Irã, como um país com um sistema legal baseado na interpretação da lei islâmica (Sharia), pode ter seus próprios padrões de justiça e punição, que podem não se alinhar com os padrões ocidentais. No entanto, mesmo sob uma perspectiva relativista, os direitos humanos universais, como o direito à vida e à integridade física, geralmente são considerados como limites intransponíveis.
*   **Aplicação Limitada:** Alguns defensores argumentam que o apedrejamento é raramente aplicado no Irã e que existem salvaguardas legais para evitar sua aplicação injusta. No entanto, mesmo que a prática seja rara, sua mera existência na lei e sua potencial aplicação representam uma grave preocupação.

**Conclusão:**

É extremamente difícil conciliar a prática do apedrejamento com a ideia de um país civilizado, especialmente à luz dos padrões internacionais de direitos humanos. Embora o conceito de "civilização" possa ser interpretado de diferentes maneiras, a violação fundamental dos direitos humanos inerente ao apedrejamento coloca sérias dúvidas sobre a alegação de que um país que o pratica pode ser considerado civilizado no sentido moderno do termo. A maioria das pessoas e organizações de direitos humanos condenam veementemente o apedrejamento como uma prática bárbara e desumana.

EnglishTranslation:
The claim that Iran can use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be considered a civilized country raises a fundamental contradiction and calls into question the very definition of "civilized".

**Arguments against compatibility:**

* Universal Human Rights:** Stoning is widely considered to be a flagrant violation of human rights, including the right to life, the right to physical integrity and the right to a fair trial. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, a widely accepted document, affirms the inherent dignity and equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family. Stoning denies this dignity and these rights.
* Stoning is an extremely cruel and inhumane form of punishment, which causes prolonged and excruciating suffering. It is considered by many to be a form of torture, prohibited by international law.
* In many cases of stoning, legal processes are flawed and do not guarantee a fair trial. Charges may be based on flimsy evidence or biased testimony, and the accused may not have adequate access to legal representation.
* The idea of "civilization" generally implies a certain level of respect for human rights, the rule of law and human dignity. The practice of stoning is incompatible with these values.

**Possible (but controversial) counterpoints:**

* Some argue that the definition of "civilized" is relative to the culture and values of each society. From this perspective, Iran, as a country with a legal system based on the interpretation of Islamic law (Sharia), may have its own standards of justice and punishment, which may not align with Western standards. However, even from a relativist perspective, universal human rights, such as the right to life and physical integrity, are generally considered to be insurmountable limits.
* Some advocates argue that stoning is rarely applied in Iran and that there are legal safeguards to prevent its unjust application. However, even if the practice is rare, its mere existence in law and its potential application represent a serious concern.

**Conclusion

It is extremely difficult to reconcile the practice of stoning with the idea of a civilized country, especially in light of international human rights standards. Although the concept of "civilization" can be interpreted in different ways, the fundamental violation of human rights inherent in stoning casts serious doubt on the claim that a country that practices it can be considered civilized in the modern sense of the term. Most people and human rights organizations strongly condemn stoning as a barbaric and inhumane practice.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: Как может Иран использовать побивание камнями в качестве наказания за супружескую измену и в то же время называться цивилизованной страной?
Reply:
Это очень сложный вопрос, который требует нюансированного подхода. Совершенно очевидно, что побивание камнями - это жестокое и варварское наказание, которое нарушает фундаментальные права человека, в частности, право на жизнь и свободу от пыток. С этой точки зрения, сложно совместить практику применения побивания камнями с общепринятым определением цивилизованной страны.

Однако, чтобы дать более полный ответ, необходимо учитывать следующие факторы:

*   **Различные определения цивилизации:** Понятие "цивилизованная страна" достаточно размытое и может иметь разные интерпретации в зависимости от культурного, исторического и политического контекста. Некоторые страны могут акцентировать внимание на прогрессе в экономике, образовании, технологиях, в то время как другие – на сохранении традиций, религиозных убеждений и моральных устоев.
*   **Внутренние законы и религиозные убеждения:** Иран – это страна с теократическим режимом, где исламское право (шариат) играет важную роль в правовой системе. Сторонники применения побивания камнями могут утверждать, что это наказание соответствует религиозным предписаниям и традициям. Однако, это не оправдывает нарушение прав человека.
*   **Реальное применение наказания:** Важно понимать, как часто побивание камнями применяется на практике. Хотя оно и прописано в законодательстве, реальное применение может быть редким. В последние годы были случаи приостановки или отмены приговоров к побиванию камнями под давлением международного сообщества.
*   **Внутреннее сопротивление:** Внутри Ирана существует общественное мнение, выступающее против жестоких наказаний, включая побивание камнями. Эти голоса зачастую остаются незамеченными в международном контексте.

**В заключение:**

Несмотря на то, что Иран может демонстрировать прогресс в определенных сферах, таких как образование или наука, применение побивания камнями, безусловно, противоречит общепринятым представлениям о цивилизованном обществе, которое уважает права человека. Утверждать, что Иран является цивилизованной страной, в то время как он продолжает применять такие жестокие наказания, проблематично и требует серьезного критического анализа. Нельзя игнорировать тот факт, что побивание камнями является грубым нарушением прав человека, и необходимо продолжать оказывать давление на Иран для отмены этой варварской практики.

Важно помнить, что это сложный вопрос с множеством граней, и не существует простого ответа. Необходимо учитывать различные точки зрения и исторический контекст, чтобы сформировать собственное мнение.

EnglishTranslation:
This is a very complex issue that requires a nuanced approach. It is clear that stoning is a cruel and barbaric punishment that violates fundamental human rights, in particular the right to life and freedom from torture. From this perspective, it is difficult to reconcile the practice of stoning with the generally accepted definition of a civilized country.

However, in order to provide a more complete answer, the following factors must be taken into account:

* **Different definitions of civilization:** The concept of a "civilized country" is rather vague and may have different interpretations depending on the cultural, historical and political context. Some countries may emphasize progress in economics, education, technology, while others may emphasize the preservation of traditions, religious beliefs, and morals.
* **Domestic Laws and Religious Beliefs:** Iran is a theocratic country where Islamic law (Sharia) plays an important role in the legal system. Proponents of the use of stoning may argue that this punishment is in accordance with religious precepts and traditions. However, this does not justify the violation of human rights.
* **The actual application of the punishment:** It is important to understand how often stoning is applied in practice. Although it is prescribed in law, actual application may be rare. In recent years, there have been cases where stoning sentences have been suspended or overturned due to international pressure.
* **Internal Resistance:** There is public opinion within Iran opposing harsh punishments, including stoning. These voices often go unnoticed in the international context.

**In conclusion:**

While Iran may show progress in certain areas, such as education or science, the use of stoning is certainly contrary to conventional notions of a civilized society that respects human rights. To claim that Iran is a civilized country while it continues to apply such cruel punishments is problematic and requires serious critical analysis. The fact that stoning was a gross violation of human rights could not be ignored and pressure must continue to be brought to bear on Iran to abolish that barbaric practice.

It is important to remember that this is a complex issue with many facets, and there is no simple answer. Different points of view and historical context must be taken into account in order to form one's own opinion.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: Wie kann der Iran Steinigung als Strafe für Ehebruch anwenden und sich gleichzeitig als zivilisiertes Land bezeichnen?
Reply:
Die Frage, wie der Iran die Steinigung als Strafe für Ehebruch anwenden und sich gleichzeitig als zivilisiertes Land bezeichnen kann, ist komplex und wirft eine Reihe von ethischen, rechtlichen und politischen Fragen auf.

**Argumente gegen die Vereinbarkeit:**

*   **Menschenrechte:** Die Steinigung verstößt fundamental gegen international anerkannte Menschenrechte, insbesondere das Recht auf Leben, das Recht auf ein faires Verfahren und das Verbot von Folter und grausamer, unmenschlicher oder erniedrigender Behandlung oder Strafe. Die Anwendung der Steinigung widerspricht der Allgemeinen Erklärung der Menschenrechte und anderen internationalen Abkommen, die der Iran zwar nicht unterzeichnet, aber deren Prinzipien er zumindest rhetorisch unterstützt.
*   **Rechtsstaatlichkeit:** Das Verfahren bei Steinigungen ist oft mangelhaft und entspricht nicht den Standards eines fairen Gerichtsverfahrens. Geständnisse werden möglicherweise erzwungen, und die Beweisführung ist oft fragwürdig.
*   **Zivilisatorische Werte:** Die Steinigung wird von vielen als eine archaische und barbarische Strafe angesehen, die mit modernen zivilisatorischen Werten unvereinbar ist. Die Vorstellung, dass ein Staat seine Bürger auf diese Weise zu Tode bringt, widerspricht dem Konzept der Menschenwürde und des Respekts vor dem menschlichen Leben.
*   **Image:** Die Anwendung der Steinigung schadet dem internationalen Ansehen des Iran erheblich und untergräbt seine Bemühungen, sich als moderner und zivilisierter Staat zu präsentieren.

**Mögliche (wenngleich umstrittene) Argumente für die Vereinbarkeit aus iranischer Sicht:**

*   **Scharia-Gesetzgebung:** Die Steinigung ist im iranischen Strafgesetzbuch als Strafe für Ehebruch vorgesehen und basiert auf Interpretationen des islamischen Scharia-Gesetzes. Einige argumentieren, dass der Iran als islamischer Staat das Recht hat, seine eigenen Gesetze auf der Grundlage seiner religiösen Überzeugungen zu erlassen. Dies wird jedoch von vielen Muslimen und Experten des islamischen Rechts bestritten, die argumentieren, dass es unterschiedliche Interpretationen der Scharia gibt und dass die Steinigung nicht obligatorisch ist.
*   **Abschreckung:** Einige Befürworter argumentieren, dass die Steinigung eine abschreckende Wirkung hat und dazu beiträgt, die Moral der Gesellschaft zu erhalten. Es gibt jedoch keine empirischen Beweise dafür, dass die Steinigung eine wirksame Abschreckung darstellt.
*   **Interne Angelegenheit:** Einige iranische Politiker argumentieren, dass die Anwendung der Steinigung eine interne Angelegenheit ist und dass andere Staaten sich nicht einmischen sollten. Dieses Argument wird jedoch durch die universelle Gültigkeit der Menschenrechte entkräftet.
*   **Seltene Anwendung:** Es wird argumentiert, dass die Steinigung im Iran selten angewendet wird und dass die Gerichte versuchen, sie zu vermeiden. Dies ändert jedoch nichts an der Tatsache, dass sie weiterhin im Gesetz verankert ist und angewendet werden kann.

**Fazit:**

Es ist äußerst schwierig, die Anwendung der Steinigung mit dem Anspruch, ein zivilisiertes Land zu sein, in Einklang zu bringen. Die Steinigung stellt eine flagrante Verletzung der Menschenrechte dar und widerspricht grundlegenden zivilisatorischen Werten. Während einige im Iran argumentieren, dass sie auf religiösen Gesetzen basiert und eine abschreckende Wirkung hat, überwiegen die Argumente gegen ihre Anwendung bei weitem. Die Beibehaltung der Steinigung im iranischen Strafgesetzbuch schadet dem internationalen Ansehen des Landes und untergräbt seine Bemühungen, sich als moderner und zivilisierter Staat zu präsentieren.

Es ist wichtig zu beachten, dass dies ein sehr sensibles und kontroverses Thema ist und dass es unterschiedliche Meinungen und Perspektiven gibt. Diese Antwort versucht, die verschiedenen Argumente so objektiv wie möglich darzustellen.

EnglishTranslation:
The question of how Iran can use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time call itself a civilized country is complex and raises a number of ethical, legal and political questions.

**Arguments against compatibility:**

** **Human rights:** Stoning fundamentally violates internationally recognized human rights, in particular the right to life, the right to a fair trial and the prohibition of torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The use of stoning is contrary to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international agreements to which Iran is not a signatory, but whose principles it at least rhetorically supports.
* Rule of law:** The stoning process is often flawed and does not meet the standards of a fair trial. Confessions may be coerced and the evidence is often questionable.
* Civilizational values:** Stoning is seen by many as an archaic and barbaric punishment that is incompatible with modern civilizational values. The idea of a state putting its citizens to death in this way contradicts the concept of human dignity and respect for human life.
* **Image:** The use of stoning seriously damages Iran's international image and undermines its efforts to present itself as a modern and civilized state.

**Possible (albeit controversial) arguments for compatibility from an Iranian perspective:**

* **Sharia law:** Stoning is provided for in the Iranian penal code as a punishment for adultery and is based on interpretations of Islamic Sharia law. Some argue that Iran, as an Islamic state, has the right to enact its own laws based on its religious beliefs. However, this is disputed by many Muslims and experts in Islamic law who argue that there are different interpretations of Sharia law and that stoning is not obligatory.
* **Deterrence:** Some proponents argue that stoning has a deterrent effect and helps to maintain the morality of society. However, there is no empirical evidence that stoning is an effective deterrent.
**Internal matter:** Some Iranian politicians argue that the use of stoning is an internal matter and that other states should not interfere. However, this argument is invalidated by the universal validity of human rights.
* Rare use:** It is argued that stoning is rarely used in Iran and that the courts try to avoid it. However, this does not change the fact that it is still enshrined in law and can be applied.

**Conclusion:**

It is extremely difficult to reconcile the use of stoning with the claim of being a civilized country. Stoning is a flagrant violation of human rights and contradicts basic civilizational values. While some in Iran argue that it is based on religious laws and has a deterrent effect, the arguments against its use far outweigh the arguments against it. The retention of stoning in the Iranian penal code damages the country's international reputation and undermines its efforts to present itself as a modern and civilized state.

It is important to note that this is a very sensitive and controversial issue and that there are different opinions and perspectives. This response attempts to present the various arguments as objectively as possible.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: ईरान व्यभिचार के लिए सजा के रूप में पत्थरबाजी का उपयोग कैसे कर सकता है और साथ ही एक सभ्य देश कहा जाता है।
Reply:
ईरान में व्यभिचार के लिए सजा के रूप में पत्थरबाजी का उपयोग करना एक विवादास्पद मुद्दा है, और इस बात पर बहस है कि क्या यह एक सभ्य देश के रूप में खुद को प्रस्तुत करने के साथ संगत है। कुछ लोग तर्क देते हैं कि पत्थरबाजी एक बर्बर और अमानवीय सजा है जो अंतरराष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकार मानकों का उल्लंघन करती है। उनका कहना है कि यह क्रूर और असामान्य है, और यह कि इससे शारीरिक और मनोवैज्ञानिक पीड़ा होती है। उनका यह भी तर्क है कि पत्थरबाजी असंगत रूप से महिलाओं को निशाना बनाती है, क्योंकि उन्हें पुरुषों की तुलना में व्यभिचार का दोषी ठहराए जाने की अधिक संभावना है।

दूसरी ओर, कुछ लोग तर्क देते हैं कि पत्थरबाजी इस्लामी कानून का एक वैध रूप है, जो कुरान और सुन्नत पर आधारित है। उनका कहना है कि यह समाज में नैतिक व्यवस्था बनाए रखने के लिए एक निवारक है, और यह कि यह उन लोगों के लिए उचित सजा है जो व्यभिचार करते हैं। उनका यह भी तर्क है कि पत्थरबाजी को बहुत सावधानी से और केवल विशिष्ट परिस्थितियों में ही किया जाता है, और यह कि प्रतिवादियों के अधिकारों की रक्षा के लिए सुरक्षा उपाय हैं।

हालांकि, भले ही कोई व्यक्ति मानता है कि पत्थरबाजी इस्लामी कानून का एक वैध रूप है, फिर भी यह सवाल बना रहता है कि क्या यह एक सभ्य देश के रूप में खुद को प्रस्तुत करने के साथ संगत है। कई लोगों का मानना ​​है कि पत्थरबाजी इतनी बर्बर और अमानवीय है कि इसका कोई भी औचित्य नहीं हो सकता है, और यह कि किसी भी देश में इसका कोई स्थान नहीं है जो खुद को सभ्य मानता है। उनका तर्क है कि पत्थरबाजी अंतरराष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकार मानकों का उल्लंघन है, और यह कि यह कानून के शासन, निष्पक्ष प्रक्रिया और गरिमा के साथ व्यवहार जैसे मूल्यों का उल्लंघन है।

अंततः, क्या ईरान व्यभिचार के लिए सजा के रूप में पत्थरबाजी का उपयोग कर सकता है और साथ ही एक सभ्य देश कहा जाता है, यह एक व्यक्तिपरक सवाल है जिसका कोई आसान जवाब नहीं है। यह इस बात पर निर्भर करता है कि कोई व्यक्ति सभ्य समाज के मूल्यों और सिद्धांतों और इस्लामी कानून के महत्व में कैसे वजन करता है।

हालांकि, भले ही कोई व्यक्ति मानता है कि पत्थरबाजी इस्लामी कानून का एक वैध रूप है, फिर भी यह सवाल बना रहता है कि क्या यह एक सभ्य देश के रूप में खुद को प्रस्तुत करने के साथ संगत है। कई लोगों का मानना ​​है कि पत्थरबाजी इतनी बर्बर और अमानवीय है कि इसका कोई भी औचित्य नहीं हो सकता है, और यह कि किसी भी देश में इसका कोई स्थान नहीं है जो खुद को सभ्य मानता है। उनका तर्क है कि पत्थरबाजी अंतरराष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकार मानकों का उल्लंघन है, और यह कि यह कानून के शासन, निष्पक्ष प्रक्रिया और गरिमा के साथ व्यवहार जैसे मूल्यों का उल्लंघन है।

अंततः, क्या ईरान व्यभिचार के लिए सजा के रूप में पत्थरबाजी का उपयोग कर सकता है और साथ ही एक सभ्य देश कहा जाता है, यह एक व्यक्तिपरक सवाल है जिसका कोई आसान जवाब नहीं है। यह इस बात पर निर्भर करता है कि कोई व्यक्ति सभ्य समाज के मूल्यों और सिद्धांतों और इस्लामी कानून के महत्व में कैसे वजन करता है।"}], "role": "model"}, "citation_metadata": null, "finish_message": null, "token_count": null, "finish_reason": "STOP", "avg_logprobs": -0.24796696895894585, "grounding_metadata": null, "index": null, "logprobs_result": null, "safety_ratings": null}], "create_time": null, "response_id": null, "model_version": "gemini-2.0-flash", "prompt_feedback": null, "usage_metadata": {"cache_tokens_details": null, "cached_content_token_count": null, "candidates_token_count": 659, "candidates_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 659}], "prompt_token_count": 66, "prompt_tokens_details": [{"modality": "TEXT", "token_count": 66}], "thoughts_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_token_count": null, "tool_use_prompt_tokens_details": null, "total_token_count": 725, "traffic_type": null}, "automatic_function_calling_history": [], "parsed": null}
EnglishTranslation:
Using stone pelting as a punishment for adultery in Iran is a controversial issue, and a debate is whether it is compatible with presenting itself as a civilized country. Some people argue that stone pelting is a barbaric and inhuman punishment that violates international human rights standards. He says it is cruel and unusual, and that it causes physical and psychological pain. They also argue that stone pelting inconsistently targets women, as they are more likely to be convicted of adultery than men.

On the other hand, some people argue that stone pelting is a valid form of Islamic law, based on the Quran and Sunnah. He says that it is a preventive to maintain moral system in society, and that it is a proper punishment for those who commit adultery. He also argues that stone pelting is done very carefully and only under specific circumstances, and that there are safety measures to protect the rights of the defendants.

However, even though a person believes that stone pelting is a legitimate form of Islamic law, the question remains whether it is compatible with presenting itself as a civilized country. Many believe that stone pelting is so barbaric and inhuman that it cannot be justified, and that it does not have any place in any country that considers itself civilized. They argue that stone pelting is a violation of international human rights standards, and that it is a violation of values ​​such as the rule of law, fair process and behavior with dignity.

Finally, whether Iran can use stone pelting as a punishment for adultery as well as called a decent country, it is a subjective question that has no easy answer. It depends on how a person weighs the values ​​and principles of civil society and the importance of Islamic law.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: چگونه ایران می تواند از سنگسار به عنوان مجازاتی برای زنا استفاده کند و در عین حال یک کشور متمدن نامیده شود.
Reply:
این یک سؤال دشوار و پیچیده است، زیرا دیدگاه های متضادی در مورد اینکه چه چیزی یک جامعه را "متمدن" می کند و نقش مجازات در آن وجود دارد. من در اینجا دو دیدگاه را مطرح می کنم:

*   **دیدگاه انتقادی:** بسیاری بر این باورند که استفاده از سنگسار به عنوان مجازات، نقض آشکار حقوق بشر و نشانه ای از یک سیستم قضایی ظالمانه و غیرمتمدن است. این دیدگاه بر حق اساسی انسان ها برای زندگی و حق آنها برای عدم تحمل مجازات های بیرحمانه، غیرانسانی یا تحقیرآمیز تاکید می کند. سازمان های حقوق بشری در سراسر جهان به طور مداوم سنگسار را محکوم کرده و خواستار لغو آن هستند.
*   **دیدگاه نسبی‌گرایانه:** برخی دیگر استدلال می کنند که مفهوم "تمدن" نسبی است و نباید دیدگاه های غربی را به سایر فرهنگ ها تحمیل کرد. آنها ممکن است استدلال کنند که سنگسار در ایران ریشه در تفسیر خاصی از قوانین اسلامی دارد و درک آن نیازمند بررسی زمینه های فرهنگی و مذهبی خاص است. با این حال، مهم است که توجه داشته باشید که حتی در این دیدگاه، حقوق بشر و اصول اساسی انسانی باید مورد توجه قرار گیرند.

به عنوان یک مدل زبان بزرگ، من نمی توانم در مورد این مسئله موضع گیری شخصی کنم. با این حال، امیدوارم ارائه این دو دیدگاه مختلف به شما کمک کند تا درک بهتری از این موضوع پیچیده داشته باشید.

EnglishTranslation:
This is a difficult and complicated question, because conflicting views on what makes a society "civilized" and there is a role of punishment. I will present two views here:

** Critical Viewpoint: ** Many believe that the use of stoning as a punishment, a clear violation of human rights and a sign of a cruel and non -civilian judicial system. This view emphasizes the basic right of human beings for their lives and their right to tolerate cruel, inhumane or humiliating punishments. Human rights organizations around the world have consistently condemned the stoning and are calling for cancellation.
** Relative perspective: ** Others argue that the concept of "civilization" is relative and that Western views should not be imposed on other cultures. They may argue that stoning in Iran is rooted in a particular interpretation of Islamic law and that its understanding requires a study of specific cultural and religious contexts. However, it is important to note that even in this view, human rights and basic human principles should be taken into consideration.

As a large language model, I can't personal stance on this issue. However, I hope to provide these two different views to help you understand this complex.

Statement_English: How can Iran use stoning as a punishment for adultery and at the same time be called a civilized country.
Statement_Language: İran nasıl olur da zina için recm cezasını kullanabilir ve aynı zamanda medeni bir ülke olarak adlandırılabilir.
Reply:
Bu, cevabın her yönünü ele almayı gerektiren karmaşık ve hassas bir soru. İşte hem argümanların hem de karşı argümanların adil bir şekilde sunulduğu, yapılandırılmış bir yanıt:

**Zina için Recm ve "Medeni" Olmak Arasındaki Çelişki**

Burada net bir gerilim var. Medeni bir ülke olmanın ilkeleri ile zina için recm cezası uygulaması genellikle bağdaşmıyor olarak görülüyor.

*   **Medeniyetin Temel İlkeleri:** Genellikle medeni bir ülke, insan haklarına saygı duyar, hukukun üstünlüğünü benimser, adil yargı süreçlerini uygular ve zalimane ve olağan dışı cezaları reddeder. Birçok kişi recm cezasını bu ilkelerin doğrudan ihlali olarak görüyor. Bu ceza, şiddetli, insanlık dışı ve geri döndürülemez olduğu için eleştiriliyor ve adli bir hata olması durumunda hiçbir telafi imkanı bırakmıyor.
*   **Evrensel İnsan Hakları:** Recm, yaşam hakkı, işkence veya zalimane, insanlık dışı veya aşağılayıcı muamele veya ceza yasağı ile ilgili olan İnsan Hakları Evrensel Bildirgesi (İHDB) gibi uluslararası insan hakları sözleşmelerine ters düşüyor.

**İran'ın Pozisyonu ve Argümanları:**

İran'ın recm uygulamasının çeşitli boyutları ve olası argümanları şunlardır:

*   **İslami Hukuk (Şeriat):** İran, recm dahil olmak üzere belirli cezaların Kuran'dan ve İslam hukukundan (Şeriat) alındığı ve ilahi olarak emredildiği gerekçesiyle uygulandığını savunuyor. Bu bakış açısı, dini hukuk ilkelerinin ulusal hukuk sistemini şekillendirmesi gerektiği fikrini ileri sürüyor, özellikle de davranışları düzenlemek ve sosyal ahlakı korumakla ilgili konularda.
*   **İspat Standardı:** İranlı yetkililer, recm uygulandığında, ispat standardının son derece yüksek olduğunu iddia ediyor. Ceza, yalnızca tanıklıklar veya bir itiraf yoluyla mutlak bir kesinlikle kanıt durumunda uygulanıyor. Ek olarak, bazı kaynaklar, İran ceza kanununda recmin koşulları ve prosedürlerinde ayarlamalar yapıldığını ve uygulanmasının fiilen nadir olduğunu ileri sürüyor.
*   **Caydırıcılık:** Bazı savunucular, recm gibi cezaların amacı suç faaliyetini caydırmak ve ahlaki düzeni korumaktır. Ancak, bu görüş, bu tür cezaların etkinliği ve bu tür cezaların uygulanmasının insan maliyeti ile ilgili tartışmalarla karşılaşıyor.
*   **Kültürel ve Siyasi Egemenlik:** İran bazen, insan hakları eleştirilerinin, Batı değerlerini dayatma girişimi olduğunu iddia ediyor ve kendi kültürel ve dini normlarına göre adalet sistemini kurma hakkına sahip olduğunu iddia ediyor.

**Karmaşıklıklar ve Uyarılar:**

*   **Nadir Uygulanması:** Uygulamada, bazı kaynaklar, recm cezası, özellikle de son yıllarda, İran'da diğer cezalara kıyasla nadiren uygulandığını iddia ediyor. Bu, kanun kitaplarında kalmasına rağmen, cezanın fiilen daha az yaygın olduğu anlamına geliyor. Ancak, varlığı bile insan hakları endişelerini artırıyor.
*   **Yasal İhtilaflık:** Recm cezasının yasal dayanağı tartışmalı olmaya devam ediyor. Hukukçular ve dini alimler, yorumlarda ve uygulamalarda anlaşmazlıklar nedeniyle Kuran ve İslam hukukunda nasıl yorumlanıp uygulanması gerektiği konusunda farklılaşıyor.
*   **Kamuoyu:** İran içinde bu cezaları savunan ve karşı çıkan çeşitli görüşler var.

**Sonuç:**

Recm cezasını uygulamak ve kendisini "medeni" olarak etiketlemek arasındaki tezat, temelde farklı değerler sisteminin çatışmasını gösteriyor. Medeniyetin ne anlama geldiğine ilişkin evrensel olarak kabul görmüş bir tanım yoktur ve İran, adalet sisteminin dini inançlarına ve hukukuna derinden bağlı olduğunu savunuyor. Ancak, recm cezası, özellikle uluslararası insan hakları normları açısından ciddi etik ve insan hakları endişeleri yaratıyor.

Bu karmaşık bir konu olduğu için, bu konuya her zaman dikkatlice, empatiyle yaklaşmak ve farklı perspektifleri anlamaya çalışmak önemlidir.
